attachments.title: Android Keystore System | Android Developers
attachments.text: The Android Keystore system lets you store cryptographic keys in a container to make it more difficult to extract from the device. Once keys are in the keystore, they can be used for cryptographic operations with the key material remaining non-exportable…

text: nice, chris lacy. i like his podcast but he focuses too much on hardware for my taste

but may i ask why do you think SharedPref isn't a good practice to store access tokens
(Btw keep in mind that you can only obfuscate stuff on the device, if they really want your key, they'll get it)
<@U061HDV96>: you can use hardware backed RSA
at least back to 15 anyways
<@U055GGAHS>: I haven't used the keystore yet, but I'm just wondering where the keys are stored then
Anybody using JaCoCo with Gradle 2.13? :confused:

<@U061HDV96>: the API has a call to determine if it is hardware backed. Even if it is not hardware backed you are generating a per device key that is in system storage and significantly more difficult to access compared to local app storage or shared preferences as both can be accessed by simply modifying a manifest to allow backups.
<@U053LEHJN>: yup

text: <@U053LEHJN>: do you have tests? haha; ok, I’ve figured out
just in androidTest
I apply jacoco for jvm tests with this <https://github.com/artem-zinnatullin/qualitymatters/blob/master/code_quality_tools/jacoco.gradle>
yeah, like I said we’re doing the same but it applies to AndroidTest, not UnitTest
For instrumentation tests you need `testCoverageEnabled`
and we have that set but it doesn’t do anything
then apply to unitTest
there is no builtin support for jvm tests coverage in Android Gradle Plugin
so you have to manually bind jacoco to such tests with something like <https://github.com/artem-zinnatullin/qualitymatters/blob/master/code_quality_tools/jacoco.gradle>
<@U055GGAHS>: ya what I thought was the case. (Still obfuscated :troll:)
But ya api tokens per device can always be reset

<@U061HDV96>: on almost all devices now RSA is hardware backed and an API key is going to be short enough an RSA key can stream the encryption. So it’s definitely encryption and not obfuscation :troll:

AES is hardware backed on a few devices so you can not rely on it to be so for at rest you can use RSA to wrap your AES key. Better than nothing but breakable probably if you can get a debugger attached
Still breakable which is what I meant. I also mean that it's not easy peasy to get it.
<@U061HDV96>:  thanks i'll take a look
the RSA is not breakable outside the use case of the sound detection methods that are becoming more prevalent. The solution there is move quickly =P
<@U091EBYSU>: soooo apparently my team lead disabled testCoverageEnabled while he was working and forgot to turn it back on when he pushed
bad <@U0547SF15>
/gif call the cops
<@U091EBYSU>: do you know of any way of excluding classes from tests with android’s built-in jacoco stuff?
<@U053LEHJN>: no, that’s one reason to do it manually :simple_smile:

<@U15FHV1FA|sakibarrahman> has joined the channel
Hey guys, What the best way to do a range with a 1 second delay in between?
range(0,45).delay(1, TimeUnit.SECONDS)?
with rxjava and observeables*

<@U0N92TLT1>: ```
private void delayTheFinish() {
        new Handler().postDelayed(new Runnable() {
            @Override
            public void run() {
                // bla bla
            }
        }, 1*1000);
    }
```
<@U0JBR7LUV>: thanks :smile: I forgot to add the rxjava part into the question
ok, but I don’t think that you need to use RxJava for 1 second delay :simple_smile:
right right, but I do things along with it
I have a couple filters as well and I unsubscribe this countdown I have when I’m off screen potentially
you don't need to use rxjava but it's certainly way easier and cleaner :stuck_out_tongue: same with most things you can do with Rx
I think you want either `throttle` or `debounce`
<@U0N92TLT1>
oooo throttle was what I was looking for
okay perfect
actually I think delay makes more sense since I just want 45 emission from the observable at 1 second intervals
I think?
would concatMap work?
how does concatMap work?
<@U08KK98UU|trevor-e> uploaded a file: <https://androidchat.slack.com/files/trevor-e/F15HGAU6R/-.java|Untitled>

file.name: -.java
file.title: Untitled
file.preview_highlight:
Observable.range(0,45)
	.concatMap(integer -> Observable.just(integer).delay(integer, TimeUnit.SECONDS))

text: hmmm interesting

but can’t you just do 
```
Observable.range(0,45).delay(1, TimeUnit.SECONDS)?
```
I don’t believe that would delay for each item range() emits
concatMap will turn each emitted item into an observable which you then delay on
